_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: All service bldg equipment, including compressors, condensor, and condenser pump
_prev_prog_3.Description: Main Ammonia Refrigeration System - The prevention program includes all the required elements of the Process Safety Management regulations including process safety information, process hazard analysis, written operating procedures, employee participation and training, mechanical integrity, pre-startup review, hot work permits, management of change, incident investigation, contractor orientation and training, and compliance safety auditing. All of these elements were reviewed and revised as appropriate for the new refrigeration system installed this year. The refrigeration department has been automated so that theoperator can view most of the refrigeration process using a computer. This system maintains the predetermined set points established by the operator, allowing the equipment to start or stop, load or unload while maintaining safe pressures. Safety devices designed to prevent and mitigate releases of ammonia include ammonia detection equipment and alarm in the service building, a computer alarm system for several vessels, control switches on the low pressure vessels with an automatic shutoff, safety relief valves throughout the refrigeration system, compressor setting cutouts, emergency stop buttons on the compressors and at each entrance to the service building, pressure and temperature sensors on the ammonia pumps, and a temperature safety on the condenser system.

_prev_prog_3.Description: Cold Storage  - The prevention program originally developed for the main existing ammonia refrigeration system at the plant has been revised to incorporate the new cold storage area. The prevention program includes all the required elements of the Process Safety Management regulations  including process safety information, process hazard analysis, written operating procedures, employee participation and training, mechanical integrity, pre-startup review, hot work permits, management of change, incident investigation, contractor orientation and training, and compliance safety auditing. All of these elements were reviewed and revised as necessary to include the refrigeration system for the new cold storage area. _exec_summary.SummaryText:
McCain Foods USA, Inc. is committed to being a responsible member of the community by giving top priority to operating in a safe and environmentally sound manner. This commitment is documented in the Easton facility?s accident prevention and emergency response plans, which are available to all employees.

McCain?s Easton facility is a potato processing plant which produces frozen potato products, such as french fries and tater tots, for the retail and service markets. Ammonia, a regulated toxic substance, is used in the refrigeration system at the facility. The main refrigeration system consists of three single stage systems. The first is a low temperature system, which provides cooling for freezer tunnels and specialty freezers. The second system is the cold storage temperature system, which provides cooling for the cold storage and loading dock areas. A third system is the high temperature system, which provides cooling for the refrigerated precool units of the process tunnels, loading dock, batter room, AC chiller, process chiller, retrograder, and for the flash liquid ammonia cooler. The maximum capacity of the main refrigeration system is approximately 55,000 pounds of ammonia. A more complete description of the refrigeration system is found in the Hazardous Materials Emergency Response Plan and in drawings developed as part of the Process Safety Management program.

A new cold storage area is being added to the ammonia refrigeration system for the facility. The refrigeration system for this new area will be a single stage system with economizer side ports, evaporative condenser, and liquid storage and distribution tanks. The main system for this new cold storage area will provide cooling for cold storage, and will consist of two single stage, rotary screw compressor packages. The economizer system will provide cooling for the dock and for the flash liquid ammonia cooler, and will also consist of two single stage, rotary screw compressor packages. The maximum c

apacity for the new cold storage area will be 26,000 pounds of ammonia. A more complete description of the new cold storage area can be found in the operating procedures and drawings developed as part of the Process Safety Management program.

Because of the relatively large distance between the new cold storage area and the existing main refrigeration system, the ammonia refrigeration system associated with the new cold storage area must be considered a separate process under USEPA's Risk Management Program regulations. The two refrigeration systems will not be physically connected, and a release from one system would not cause a release from the other system. The new cold storage area is considered a Program 3 process, as it will be subject to OSHA's Process Safety Management rules.

The entire ammonia refrigeration system, including the new cold storage area,  has been equipped with safeguards to prevent, detect, and mitigate accidental releases of ammonia. These safety systems are described in detail in the facility?s Hazardous Materials Emergency Response Plan and Process Safety Management program files. Included is ammonia detection equipment installed in the ceiling of the service building, which will trigger an alarm on the computer and in the service building should ammonia concentrations exceed a specified level. The refrigeration department has been automated so that the operator can view most of the refrigeration process using the Man Machine Interface RS View Computer. This system maintains the predetermined set points established by the operator, allowing the equipment to start or stop, load or unload while maintaining safe pressures. Control systems have been designed to maintain operating parameters within acceptable limits. The system is equipped with alarms and monitors to alert personnel when the operating parameters exceed the acceptable limits. The facility also conducts training of personnel to familiarize them with operation of the ammonia ref

rigeration system, safety systems and procedures, and actions to be taken should a release of ammonia occur. 

The facility complies with OSHA?s Process Safety Management regulation and with the USEPA?s Accidental Release Prevention regulations, 40 CFR Part 68, as well as applicable state and local regulations. During the past five years, there have been no accidents involving ammonia at the facility that caused onsite deaths, injuries, or significant property damage or known offsite deaths, injuries, property damage, environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place.

The facility has developed an emergency response program, which has been revised to include the new cold storage area. The emergency response program has been designed to minimize the effects of any accidental releases of ammonia on employees, the public, and the environment. The facility has a trained emergency response team, appropriate equipment and supplies, and a detailed emergency preparedness plan. During a chemical emergency, the Facility Emergency Coordinator (FEC) coordinates the response within the facility. The FEC is also the primary liaison between the facility and local, State, and Federal emergency responders. In the event of a release of ammonia above 100 pounds and/or a release that could potentially extend beyond the facility?s boundaries, it is the company?s policy to notify the local emergency response agency, the State Police, the Easton fire department, and the National Response Center, as well as key McCain personnel. A mutual aid agreement exists between the facility and the Easton fire department.

As a result of the new ammonia refrigeration system installed at the facility in 1999 and the new cold storage area, all prevention, safety, and emergency response procedures have been recently reviewed and revised as appropriate. Additional safety improvements are not currently planned.

This facility does not yet have a Clean Air Operating Permit number.
